abstract.text: Learn about important changes to AppKit.

inlineContent.text: Browse notable changes in
Organize your windows’ display and layout with window tiling.
Use SwiftUI menus in AppKit with the
Animate AppKit views using SwiftUI animations using
Use the keyboard to open context menus for UI elements on which you are focused currently.
Highlight text and choose from a number of highlight color schemes with
Add repeat, wiggle, bounce, and rotate effects to
Leverage predefined content types when saving files using the new format picker on
Resize frames and zoom in and out with new
APIs such as
and
Control whether your toolbars display text as well as icons using the
property.
Offer customized type-ahead suggestions in NSTextField using the
Use the new
delegate method on
to toggle the visibility of table columns.
Use a new
property to observe progress of an ongoing task.
Simplify how you display and style buttons with the new
bezel style. This bezel style adapts to the most appropriate style based on the contents of the button, as well as its location in the view hierarchy.
Display additional contextual information about currently selected documents with
inspectors.
New improvements to
enable you to anchor popovers from toolbar items, as well as support full-size popovers.
Explore new UI elements in
. Group information more easily in section headers, lay out menu items in horizontal palettes, as well as display badge counts on menu items.
App activation is now driven by the user, preventing unexpected switches between apps.
Take advantage of Cooperative Activation, where your apps can yield and accept activation from other apps on the system without interrupting the user’s workflows. For more information, see the
function on
and
and
are now interoperable. You can create a
from a
and vice versa.
Leverage
to synchronize your app’s ability to draw to the refresh of the display.
Create consistent, great visuals for your controls by taking advantage of standard system fill
, and
Views no longer clip their contents by default. This includes any drawing done by the view and its subviews. For more information, see the
property on
Animate symbol images with the new
function on
. Symbol effects include: bounce, pulse, variable color, scale, appear, disappear, and replace.
Display and manipulate high dynamic range (HDR) images.
AppKit more fully integrates with Swift and SwiftUI with Sendable (
) and Transferable (
) types.
Preview your views and view controllers alongside your code using the new
Swift macro. Incrementally adopt SwiftUI into your AppKit life cycle by leveraging modifiers like toolbar and navigation title on
Simplify your code with new attributes,
and
, to help with view and window loading.
Help people enter text more effectively with the
that adapts to the current accent color of the app. Cursor accessories also help users visualize where and how to enter text.
Simplify
entry by leveraging the new
AutoFill feature, making it more convenient to enter types such as contact information, birthdays, names, credit cards, and street addresses.
Adopt text styles like
, and
on

to take advantage of enhancements to the font system, like improved hyphenation for non-English languages and dynamic line-height adjustments for languages that require more vertical space. Access localized variants of symbol images by specifying a locale.

abstract.text: View major documentation updates and highlights from WWDC, browse ongoing updates from a set of framework releases over time, and jump to the latest release notes.
Learn about important changes to ARKit.
Learn about important changes to AVFAudio.
Learn about important changes to AVFoundation.
Learn about important changes to Accelerate.
Learn about important changes to Accessibility.
Learn about important changes in ActivityKit.
Learn about important changes to AdAttributionKit.
Learn about important changes in App Intents.
Learn about important changes to Apple Intelligence.
Learn about important changes to Apple Pencil.
Learn about important changes to Audio Toolbox.
Learn about important changes to AuthenticationServices.
Learn about important changes to Bundle Resources.
Learn about important changes to ContactsUI.
Learn about important changes to Core Location.
Animates changes to one or more views using the specified SwiftUI animation.
The direction in which a rectangular frame can be resized.
The position along the perimeter of a rectangular frame (its edges and corners) from which it’s resized.
The delegate that provides text suggestions for the receiving text field and responds to the user highlighting and selecting items.

Whether or not the user is allowed to change display modes at run time. This functionality is independent of customizing the order of the items themselves. Only disable when the functionality or legibility of your toolbar could not be improved by another display mode. The user’s selection will be persisted using the toolbar’s `identifier` when `autosavesConfiguration` is enabled. The default is YES for apps linked on macOS 15.0 and above.
An AppKit menu with menu items that are defined by a SwiftUI View.
Constants that specify the type of highlight to apply to text.

featured.svg.alt: An icon, with a star and a speech bubble around it, representing updates.
